Description.val: This line item funds modifications to a group of trainer aircraft which includes T-44A/C and TH-57.  The trainer aircraft are described as follows:  The T-44 is a twin-engine, multi-seat turboprop aircraft produced by Hawker Beech Aircraft used to simulate operation of multi engine aircraft, specifically the P-3; the TH-57 is a single-engine, multi-seat rotary wing aircraft used for helicopter training. The overall goal of the modification is to maintain safe and reliable operation of the trainer aircraft through the timely installation of necessary changes. Total numbers for T-44 and TH-57 aircraft are 54 and 126, respectively.

Name.@footnote: Increase FY14 to FY15 Training equipment required to retrofit the trainers to be current with the modifications in this OSIP.

Name.val: 2.1.3) Digital Engine Gauges - "O" level installation - Organic

ImplementationMethodName.val: FRC SE Government Field Mod Team : Installation Name: Install Kits
Organic - Digital Engine Gauges - "O" level installation

Description.val:
The T-44A Avionics are becoming unsupportable due to non-availability of parts.   The following analog avionics systems require replacement: NCS-31A Area Navigation/Control System, AP-106 Autopilot, Flight Director, digital engine gauges and the RDR-130 Weather Radar. Following these avionics obsolescence modifications, the T-44A aircraft are re-designated T-44Cs. Avionics are being returned from the repair vendor Beyond Economical Repair (BER) due to non-availability of parts.  As avionics become BER due to lack of parts, spares are being depleted and are not available in the commercial market.  Lack of avionics will ground aircraft and severely degrade Chief of Naval Air Training's ability to meet Pilot Training Requirements.  Current plans call for T-44 to fly its training mission until 2025. There are currently 20 T-44A in the inventory and all 20 will receive this modification for a total of 54 T-44Cs.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS / MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  
The T-44 Avionics Obsolescence (Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program 005-04) non-recurring engineering occurred in FY04.   Commercially available Non-Development Item kit procurement began in FY05 and installations in FY05.  Beginning in FY13, kits were commercially procured via a Fleet Support Team (FST) contract and installed by Fleet Readiness Center Southeast (FRCSE).  In FY14, kits will continue to be commercially procured via FST contract and installed by FRCSE.

Name.@footnote: In FY17, data pubs will be procured as part of the upgrade to comply with NextGen requirements.
FY16 begins simulator and courseware upgrade. Variance per FY relates to the mix being procured.
In FY18, ILS is required for Information Assurance and Information Technology approval.
The spike in labor from FY14 to FY15 was due to miscellaneous adjustments.
In FY16 and out, kits will be procured as part of the upgrade to comply with NextGen requirements.
In FY16 and out, kits will be procured as part of the upgrade to comply with NextGen requirements.

Description.val:
The TH-57 is the sole platform for primary and advanced helicopter flight training for student aviators and foreign military pilots (United States Navy, United States Marine Corps, United States Coast Guard). This modernization effort capitalizes on technology improvements to aircraft and Ground Based Training Systems (GBTS) in order to comply with Federal Aviation Regulation (FAR) national airspace NextGen requirements by FY20. The effort includes upgrading the aircraft's avionics components, installation of new hardware, and procuring new GBTS to support NextGen compliance and to satisfy documented requirement gaps. GBTS includes full flight simulator training devices, cockpit procedural trainers, computer based training courseware and hardware. A recent technical evaluation by Naval Air Warfare Center Training Systems Division (NAWCTSD) determined that purchasing new GBTS in support of the aircraft modification presented a lower cost and technical risk than modifying the current antiquated GBTS. This decision has resulted in a schedule adjustment and realignment of funding to properly align GBTS and aircraft modification delivery timelines. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  
The components of this block upgrade will be Commercial Off The Shelf.

Name.@footnote: Installations are funded out of OSIP 05-04, Avionics Obsolescence; FY13 and FY14 kits are installed same year manufactured.
Concurrent with Avionics Upgrade Modification at Fleet Readiness Center NAS Jacksonville. 1. Installs funded out of OSIP 05-04.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Concurrent with Avionics Upgrade Modification at Fleet Readiness Center NAS Jacksonville : Installat

Description.val:
The Naval Air Systems Command Wiring System Team, AIR-4.4.4.3, completed a Wiring Integrity Study on the T-44A in FY02 and identified that the aircraft wiring, outside the pressure vessel, has deteriorated to an unacceptable condition.  It was recommended that the wiring in the wings, from pressure vessel outward (including the engines) be replaced.  Current Navy long-term plans are to operate the T-44A aircraft until the year 2025. In order to safely and economically maintain aircraft availability and Pilot Training Requirements, it is necessary to replace the wiring.  Note that aircraft designated T-44A are redesignated T-44C upon completion of Avionics Obsolescence (Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program 005-04) Modifications.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Wing rewire will be accomplished in conjunction with Avionics Upgrade Mod (OSIP 05-04). Fleet Readiness Center Southeast (FRCSE) is now able to fabricate the wiring kits. In FY13, kits were not procured via Fleet Support Team (FST) contract, but fabricated by FRCSE; this will continue through FY14.
